DataElement.preferredDefinition: A participant's personal medical history specific for identifying breast disease and procedures.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: the medical history of a patient.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredDefinition: An account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredName: Chronic or Associated Diseases and Exposures
ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: chronic diseases, as well as diseases and exposures associated with cancer.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A participant's personal medical history specific for identifying breast disease and procedures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign (noncancerous) condition in which tissue has certain abnormal features.

Concepts.definition: A benign (noncancerous) condition in which tissue has certain abnormal features.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a needle for examination under a microscope. Also called needle biopsy.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (beh-NINE) Not cancerous; does not invade nearby tissue or spread to other parts of the body.: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the breast. Representative examples of non-neoplastic disorders include fibrocystic disease, gynecomastia, and mastitis. Representative examples of neoplastic disorders include fibroadenoma, lobular neoplasia, carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.

Concepts.definition: For neoplasms, a non-infiltrating and non-metastasizing neoplastic process that is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (e.g., severe atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, tumor cell necrosis, and abnormal mitoses). For other conditions, a process that is mild in nature and not dangerous to health.

A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the breast. Representative examples of non-neoplastic disorders include fibrocystic disease, gynecomastia, and mastitis. Representative examples of neoplastic disorders include fibroadenoma, lobular neoplasia, carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lesion characterized by the proliferation of atypical or dysplastic cells without evidence of stromal invasion.

Concepts.definition: A lesion characterized by the proliferation of atypical or dysplastic cells without evidence of stromal invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Diagnostic tests fail to detect presence of disease.

Concepts.definition: Diagnostic tests fail to detect presence of disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Tests, examinations, evaluations used to determine a subject's status or response to intervention.
ConceptualDomain.changeDescription: Created initially to support CCR value domain for CTMS.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ClassificationSchemeItems.longName: Unconjugated Isoflavones in Women at High Risk for Breast Cancer
